questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and dyslipidemia is brought to the ER because of reports of palpitations and dizziness. The ECG is shown in the image. His temperature is 36.8°C, pulse rate is 106/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 84/46 mm Hg, and SpO2 is 92% on room air. What is the next step?

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with a history of dyslipidemia, hypertension, and aortic sclerosis presents to the emergency department with chest pain. He took 3 NTG tablets with no relief. questions.text: A 70-year-old man presented with chest pain and was noted to have 2 mm of ST-segment elevation in his inferior leads. He has a systolic blood pressure (SBP) of 84 mm Hg and a heart rate (HR) of 124 beats/min. On examination, he is disoriented, jugular venous pressure (JVP) is elevated, and his lungs are clear. Which of the following is the best treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) IV Normal Saline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ right ventricular infarction (RVMI)
  • ➤ hypotension
  • ➤ clear lungs
  • ➤ IV normal saline

questions.text: A 68-year-old gentleman is brought into your ER after a syncope. The monitor showed a heart rate of 190 bpm with a blood pressure of 85/50 mmHg. His SpO2 is 98% (on NRPBM). The ECG shows a regular wide complex tachycardia (WCT) with no apparent P waves. With regard to the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform, which of these features would you expect to see?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cannon a waves

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In ventricular tachycardia with AV dissociation , you would expect to see cannon a waves on the JVP waveform, resulting from the atria contracting against closed AV valves due to the lack of synchronization between atrial and ventricular contractions.
  • ➤ ventricular tachycardia
  • ➤ AV dissociation
  • ➤ cannon a waves

questions.text: A female patient with infertility presents with galactorrhea. Evaluation reveals a 7mm prolactinoma. She is worried about her chances of conception. What is the appropriate drug in this situation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bromocriptine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ prolactinoma
  • ➤ trying to conceive
  • ➤ bromocriptine

questions.text: Which among the following, according to the latest guidelines, is NOT an indication for infective endocarditis (IE) prophylaxis?

options.label: B
options.text: Mitral Valve Prolapse with severe MR

questions.correct_answer: B. Mitral Valve Prolapse with severe MR
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mitral Valve Prolapse with severe MR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ According to the latest guidelines, mitral valve prolapse with severe mitral regurgitation is not an indication for infective endocarditis prophylaxis, while other high-risk conditions such as prior IE, unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, and cardiac transplant with valvulopathy are .
  • ➤ mitral valve prolapse with severe mitral regurgitation
  • ➤ not
  • ➤ are

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a past medical history of coronary artery disease develops an MI. He got treated in CCU and before he is discharged, he undergoes echocardiography, which reveals a left ventricular ejection fraction of 35% to 40%. He is asymptomatic. What is this patient’s heart failure stage?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Stage B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ structural heart disease
  • ➤ no symptoms
  • ➤ Stage B
  • ➤ ACC/AHA heart failure stages

questions.text: Laboratory investigations of a patient being evaluated for jaundice show elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels. Levels of the remaining liver enzymes are normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Obstructive jaundice

  • ➤ Educational Objective: Obstructive jaundice
  • ➤ bilirubin

questions.text: A woman presents with fever, arthralgia, ulcers, and fatigue for the past six months, along with new-onset hematuria. Urine examination reveals RBC casts and proteinuria. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lupus nephritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) symptoms and renal involvement (hematuria, RBC casts, and proteinuria) makes lupus nephritis the most likely diagnosis.
  • ➤ systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) symptoms
  • ➤ renal involvement
  • ➤ lupus nephritis

questions.text: An 11-year-old child who weighs 26 kg with a history of streptococcal pharyngitis presents with fever and arthralgia. There is no past history of rheumatic heart disease, carditis, or valvular disease. How often is benzathine penicillin recommended for the prophylaxis of rheumatic heart disease?

options.label: A
options.text: 600000 IU once in 3 weeks for 5 years

options.label: B
options.text: 600000 IU once in 3 weeks for 10 years

options.label: C
options.text: 1200000 IU once in 3 weeks for 10 years

options.label: D
options.text: 1200000 IU once in 3 weeks for life

questions.correct_answer: B. 600000 IU once in 3 weeks for 10 years
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 600000 IU once in 3 weeks for 10 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 27 kg
  • ➤ no history of carditis
  • ➤ 600000 IU
  • ➤ benzathine penicillin
  • ➤ 21 years of age
  • ➤ 10 years

questions.text: A man on diuretics presents with weakness. An ECG was done which showed flat T waves and prominent U waves. What is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A male patient presents to the emergency department. The arterial blood gas (ABG) report is as follows: pH = 7.2 pCO2 = 81 mm Hg HCO3- = 40 meq/L Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

  • ➤ elevated HCO3-
  • ➤ low pH

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, jaundice, and malaise. Based on the following serology reports, what is the most incorrect diagnosis? Anti-HBc : Positive HBsAg : Negative Anti-HBs : Negative HBeAg : Negative
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chronic HBV infection

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aortic regurgitation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ diastolic murmur
  • ➤ left 3rd intercostal space

questions.text: An elderly male patient was brought by his son because he was not using his left arm for day-to-day functioning. He has an unkempt appearance on the left side of his body and has a history of bumping into door frames while walking through them. The evaluation performed is shown in the image (clock drawing). Where does a lesion in the brain cause this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Right parietal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective: Left-sided hemineglect
  • ➤ right parietal lobe

questions.text: A person with dyspnea has a slight limitation in physical activity. Doing ordinary activities causes symptoms, but he is asymptomatic at rest. Which class of the New York Heart Association (NYHA) classification does he belong to?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Class II

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A patient who has slight limitations in physical activity but is asymptomatic at rest falls under NYHA Class II . Ordinary activities, such as walking or climbing stairs, result in symptoms.
  • ➤ slight limitations in physical activity
  • ➤ asymptomatic at rest
  • ➤ NYHA Class II

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with headache and bitemporal hemianopia. Hormonal evaluation was normal. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gonadotroph adenoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ normal hormonal evaluation
  • ➤ headache
  • ➤ bitemporal hemianopia
  • ➤ gonadotroph adenoma
  • ➤ non-functioning pituitary adenoma

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with prolonged menstrual bleeding. Her investigations showed normal platelet count, PT, and aPTT, while bleeding time was increased. Ristocetin test was normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ prolonged menstrual bleeding
  • ➤ increased bleeding time
  • ➤ normal Ristocetin test

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with chronic pain in his hands, knees, and hips, which is aggravated by activities such as climbing stairs. He reports increased hand pain when writing or typing. He also experiences morning stiffness in his joints, lasting around 30 minutes. An X-ray of his knee shows narrowed joint space with osteophytes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Osteoarthritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of chronic joint pain , morning stiffness lasting less than 1 hour , and X-ray findings of narrowed joint space with osteophytes is most consistent with osteoarthritis , a common non-inflammatory degenerative joint disease.
  • ➤ chronic joint pain
  • ➤ morning stiffness lasting less than 1 hour
  • ➤ X-ray findings
  • ➤ narrowed joint space with osteophytes
  • ➤ osteoarthritis

questions.text: A patient presents with frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis. A 24-hour urine volume was measured to be 7 liters, and the urine osmolarity was 260 mOsm/L. An ADH assay was performed, with a result of 0.8 pg/ml. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Central Diabetes Insipidus (DI)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with low ADH levels , polyuria , and dilute urine , the most likely diagnosis is Central Diabetes Insipidus (DI) , where there is a deficiency of ADH leading to the inability of the kidneys to concentrate urine.
  • ➤ low ADH levels
  • ➤ polyuria
  • ➤ dilute urine
  • ➤ Central Diabetes Insipidus (DI)

questions.text: Which of the following is confirmatory to ensure that a central line is in the jugular vein?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chest X-ray

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most confirmatory method to ensure that a central line is placed correctly in the jugular vein or other central venous locations is a chest X-ray , which helps visualize the position of the catheter tip and detect any complications.
  • ➤ jugular vein
  • ➤ chest X-ray

questions.text: A 23-year-old medical student with a 2-month history of palpitations, sweating, restlessness, and complains of sweaty palms. Which of the following will help in diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ultrasensitive thyrotropin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient presenting with symptoms suggestive of thyrotoxicosis , the most appropriate first step is to measure TSH with an ultrasensitive thyrotropin test to confirm the diagnosis before moving on to other investigations.
  • ➤ thyrotoxicosis
  • ➤ TSH
  • ➤ ultrasensitive thyrotropin

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman who recently received a kidney transplant 2 months ago developed a high-grade fever, dyspnea, and a hacking cough. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral interstitial infiltrates. Urine examination shows “owl eye” appearance of cells. Which of the following agents is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cytomegalovirus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ "owl eye" inclusions
  • ➤ Cytomegalovirus (CMV)

questions.text: A 45-year-old presents with chest pain, dyspnea that worsens when lying down and is relieved when sitting upright. On examination, heart sounds are muffled and the lungs are clear. A chest X-ray is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cardiac Tamponade

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of dyspnea, chest pain relieved by sitting upright , muffled heart sounds , and X-ray findings (likely showing an enlarged heart silhouette) strongly suggests cardiac tamponade . This is a medical emergency that requires prompt diagnosis and treatment.
  • ➤ dyspnea, chest pain relieved by sitting upright
  • ➤ muffled heart sounds
  • ➤ cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A patient is a known case of hypertension is on multiple anti-hypertensive drugs. His ECG is shown below. Which drug is responsible for the following ECG?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Spironolactone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Spironolactone can lead to hyperkalemia , which manifests on ECG with tall T waves , widened QRS complexes , and potential absent P waves . This is the most likely cause of the ECG changes in this hypertensive patient on multiple antihypertensive medications.
  • ➤ Spironolactone
  • ➤ hyperkalemia
  • ➤ tall T waves
  • ➤ widened QRS complexes
  • ➤ absent P waves

questions.text: A morbidly obese diabetic woman was on Metformin but could not achieve glycemic control. She has had a previous osteoporotic fracture and has a history of pancreatitis. The patient does not want to take injections. Which of the following would be suitable to reduce her glucose levels?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Empagliflozin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ morbidly obese
  • ➤ osteoporosis
  • ➤ pancreatitis
  • ➤ Empagliflozin
  • ➤ weight loss

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) gets pregnant. She is currently on hydroxychloroquine and sulfasalazine, but her disease is progressively worsening at 32 weeks of gestation. Which drug can she be started on?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Certolizumab

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For pregnant women with rheumatoid arthritis , Certolizumab is the safest TNF-alpha inhibitor that can be used throughout pregnancy, particularly in the later stages, because it does not cross the placenta.
  • ➤ rheumatoid arthritis
  • ➤ Certolizumab
  • ➤ TNF-alpha inhibitor

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is referred for evaluation due to a 5-year history of Raynaud phenomenon and thickening of the skin over her fingers. Routine laboratory tests are within normal limits. DLCO (diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide) is 44% of normal, with normal lung volumes. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Restrictive lung disease secondary to pleural disease

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pulmonary hypertension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ systemic sclerosis
  • ➤ pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH)
  • ➤ reduced DLCO
  • ➤ normal lung volumes

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient with chronic hepatitis B who is HBeAg negative is evaluated for treatment. ALT is normal and HBV DNA is 800 IU/mL. Which of the following would you recommend for treatment?

Ans. D) Observation

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ chronic hepatitis B

  • ➤ HBV DNA < 2000 IU/mL
  • ➤ normal ALT
  • ➤ observation

questions.text: Which of the following is likely with ascitic fluid protein 1.9 g/dL and a SAAG (Serum-Ascites Albumin Gradient) of 1.4?

questions.text: A 72-year-old pilot presents to a neurologist with rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, ataxia, and visual disturbances. EEG showed periodic complexes. What is the most likely diagnosis?

  • ➤ myoclonus
  • ➤ ataxia
  • ➤ periodic complexes

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with a history of recurrent headaches presented for further evaluation. questions.text: A 65-year-old man is evaluated for shortness of breath on exertion and dry cough that have worsened over the course of 6 months. He has clubbing, and his vitals are stable. Pulmonary function tests (PFT) reveal: FEV1: 65% FVC: 67% FEV1/FVC: 74% TLC: 68% DLCO: 62% Which test is most likely to determine the etiology?

questions.text: A physician reviewed a patient’s chest X-ray and diagnosed COPD. The patient’s room air SaO2 is 88% and paO2 is 54 mm Hg. Which of the following will improve survival?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A patient is brought to the OPD by his wife who reports that he has difficulty expressing emotions. On examination, resting tremors and rigidity are present. Which part of the brain among the following options is primarily affected in this disease?

questions.text: A patient presents with sensory loss and weakness of limbs for 3 months. He also has angular stomatitis. On examination, there is loss of proprioception and vibration sensations, UMN-type weakness of the lower limbs, and absent ankle reflexes. What is the probable diagnosis?

questions.correct_answer: D. Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

questions.text: A patient with a long history of alcoholism presents with acute pain and swelling of the left great toe. Synovial fluid analysis shows raised leucocytes. Investigation shows normal serum uric acid levels. What is the likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A farmer tried to commit suicide by ingesting about 2 glasses of paraquat. What is the primary system affected in paraquat toxicity?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pulmonary

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ paraquat poisoning
  • ➤ pulmonary system
  • ➤ acute lung injury
  • ➤ pulmonary fibrosis

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with complaints of chest pain, palpitation, and shortness of breath. On auscultation, a mid-diastolic murmur is heard, and on examination, a prominent 'a' wave on the JVP is noted. What is the most appropriate diagnosis among the following options?

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of early morning backache and stiffness that improves with exercise and persistent red eyes. On examination, lung expansion was less than 3 cm. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ankylosing Spondylitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective: Ankylosing Spondylitis
  • ➤ morning back pain
  • ➤ stiffness that improves with exercise
  • ➤ reduced chest expansion
  • ➤ extra-articular manifestations

questions.text: FeNO in bronchial asthma is related to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Eosinophilic inflammation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In bronchial asthma , FeNO is primarily used to assess eosinophilic inflammation , which is associated with TH2-type inflammation. Elevated FeNO levels can help in guiding the use of biologic therapies for asthma.
  • ➤ bronchial asthma
  • ➤ FeNO
  • ➤ eosinophilic inflammation
  • ➤ TH2-type
  • ➤ biologic therapies

questions.text: A patient presents with severe restlessness and tremors to the emergency department. She has a history of bronchial asthma. On examination, a swollen neck is observed, and her blood pressure and heart rate are elevated. An ECG shows atrial fibrillation. Which of the following drugs can be given in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Diltiazem

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ thyrotoxicosis-induced atrial fibrillation
  • ➤ bronchial asthma
  • ➤ diltiazem

questions.text: A patient undergoing hemodialysis for hyperkalemia and raised urea levels develops drowsiness, has a seizure, and becomes hypotensive during the procedure. What can be given for treatment in this condition?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 62-year-old smoker presents with shortness of breath (SOB) on exertion. Resting SpO2 is 94%, which reduces to 85% after walking 100 meters. Examination reveals bilateral end-inspiratory crackles. The chest CT (shown) reveals honeycombing and a pattern consistent with pulmonary fibrosis. A serologic workup for autoimmune disease is unremarkable. What is the next therapeutic option?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nintedanib

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A soldier operating in the Siachen Glacier presents with numbness of his legs. Based on the image provided, which of the following statements is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Rewarming is the treatment of choice

questions.correct_answer: A. Rewarming is the treatment of choice
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rewarming is the treatment of choice

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of frostbite , like that seen in the image, rewarming is the immediate treatment of choice. Pain management is important, and in severe cases, other interventions such as thrombolytics or, in extreme situations, amputation may be considered.
  • ➤ frostbite
  • ➤ rewarming

questions.text: A 23-year-old man with Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) was treated successfully with the ABVD regimen. Which of the following drugs used in the treatment of this patient is cell cycle specific?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Plant alkaloids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Plant alkaloids , like vinblastine , are cell cycle-specific agents used in the treatment of Hodgkin lymphoma as part of the ABVD regimen, and they primarily affect cells during the M phase (mitosis) of the cell cycle.
  • ➤ Plant alkaloids
  • ➤ vinblastine
  • ➤ M phase (mitosis)

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents to the ER with the acute onset of ataxia. Neurological examination shows loss of pain and temperature sensation from the face on the left side and loss of pain and temperature sensation from the right half of the body. He also has dysarthria, dysphagia, and diminished gag reflex with ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis on the left. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lateral medullary syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ crossed sensory loss
  • ➤ dysarthria
  • ➤ dysphagia
  • ➤ Horner’s syndrome
  • ➤ lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome)
  • ➤ posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA)

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with severe peripheral arterial disease (PAD) is hospitalized for chest pain and undergoes coronary angiography (CAG). His serum creatinine is unchanged 3 days post-procedure, but from day 4, it slowly rises to a peak of 2.4 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows no proteinuria or red blood cells, and a few granular casts are present. Serum complement is low. Which one of the following is likely?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Atheroembolic disease

questions.text: A patient comes to the ER with a headache, describing it as the worst headache of his life. Initial NCCT (non-contrast CT) shows subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). What is the next step?

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ CT Angiography (CTA)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of gentamicin-related AKI?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acute tubular necrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: All of the following would be important for the prevention of tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) EXCEPT:

options.label: B
options.text: Administration of IV fluids at a minimum of 3000 mL/m² daily

options.label: C
options.text: Alkalinization of the urine by administration of NaHCO3

options.label: D
options.text: Frequent monitoring of serum chemistries every 4 hours

questions.correct_answer: C. Alkalinization of the urine by administration of NaHCO3
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Alkalinization of the urine by administration of NaHCO3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While hydration , allopurinol , and frequent serum monitoring are critical in tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) prevention, urine alkalinization is not recommended because it increases the risk of kidney complications, such as calcium phosphate precipitation .
  • ➤ hydration
  • ➤ allopurinol
  • ➤ frequent serum monitoring
  • ➤ tumor lysis syndrome (TLS)
  • ➤ urine alkalinization
  • ➤ not recommended
  • ➤ calcium phosphate precipitation

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman comes to the ER complaining of bleeding due to Warfarin. She received IV vitamin K, 4 U PRBCs, and 4 U FFP. Eight hours later, she begins to complain of SOB. Her vitals are T - 39°C, RR 35/min, SpO2 84% on room air, and BP 100/52 mm Hg. Exam reveals bilateral crackles, and the patient was intubated for respiratory failure. A chest X-ray (CXR) is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding MAFLD (Metabolic dysfunction-associated fatty liver disease) treatment EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Bariatric surgery is safe in patients with MAFLD

options.label: B
options.text: Vitamin E is helpful in reducing steatosis

options.label: C
options.text: Statins may worsen inflammation in MAFLD

options.label: D
options.text: Resmetirom is the only FDA-approved drug in MAFLD

questions.correct_answer: C. Statins may worsen inflammation in MAFLD
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Statins are safe and do not worsen inflammation in patients with MAFLD.
  • • They are commonly prescribed for dyslipidemia, a frequent comorbidity in MAFLD, and studies confirm that statins do not exacerbate liver inflammation.
  • • Moreover, statins help reduce cardiovascular risk, which is significantly increased in patients with MAFLD.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Bariatric surgery is safe in patients with MAFLD - It improves insulin sensitivity, weight, and liver histology.
  • • Option A) Bariatric surgery is safe in patients with MAFLD
  • • Option B) Vitamin E is helpful in reducing steatosis - Especially beneficial in non-diabetic patients with biopsy-proven MASH.
  • • Option B) Vitamin E is helpful in reducing steatosis
  • • Option D) Resmetirom is the only FDA-approved drug in MAFLD - Resmetirom (a selective thyroid hormone receptor-β agonist) is the first FDA-approved therapy for MASH with fibrosis, a subset of MAFLD.
  • • Option D) Resmetirom is the only FDA-approved drug in MAFLD
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Statins do not worsen liver inflammation in MAFLD and are considered safe and beneficial for cardiovascular risk management.
